description: The obsolete adjective is borrowed from French ridicule, from Latin rīdiculus (“laughable, comical, amusing, absurd, ridiculous”), from ridere (“to laugh”).
The noun is either from French, noun use of adjective, or from Latin rīdiculum, noun use of neuter of rīdiculus.
The verb is from the noun or else from French ridiculer, from ridicule.

adjectives.description: ridicule (comparative more ridicule, superlative most ridicule)

entries.meaning: derision; mocking or humiliating words or behaviour
examples: Safe from the Bar, the Pulpit, and the Throne, / Yet touch'd and sham'd by Ridicule alone.

entries.meaning: An object of sport or laughter; a laughing stock.
examples: [Marlborough] was so miserably ignorant, that his deficiencies made him the ridicule of his contemporaries.

entries.meaning: The quality of being ridiculous; ridiculousness.

verbs.description: ridicule (third-person singular simple present ridicules, present participle ridiculing, simple past and past participle ridiculed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to criticize or disapprove of someone or something through scornful jocularity; to make fun of
examples: His older sibling constantly ridiculed him with sarcastic remarks.

description: From French ridicule, probably jocular alteration of réticule.

entries.meaning: (now historical) A small woman's handbag; a reticule. [from 18th c.]
examples: I hastily drew my empty hand from my Ridicule.
